revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=January 2011}} '''Adorján Czipleá''' (1639–1664) was a Hungarian [[Christian Kabbalist]] and [[mysticism|mystic]]. Not much is known about his life except for the fact that in 1662 – after some years of formal education in his native country – he journeyed to England in order to continue his [[philosophical]] and [[theological]] studies. There is no knowledge regarding the circumstances of his death, which occurred within two years after his arrival.
While in England, Czipleá wrote a controversial short treatise entitled ''De ente et malo'' (''On Being and Evil'') which circulated among a narrow group of prominent European intellectuals including, among others, [[Henry More]], [[Joseph Glanvill]], [[Thomas Vaughan (philosopher)|Thomas Vaughan]] and [[Franciscus Mercurius van Helmont]]. Although this work appears to be lost, records of its radical views (indictable for heresy at the time) survived in contemporary accounts of it. Probably the most detailed of these accounts is found in [[Méric Casaubon]]'s letter to [[Edward Stillingfleet]], dated September 1670:
{{Quotation|One such queer scholar was Mr. Adorján Czipleá, who held that the fallen angels did nevertheless not fall from Being since they possesse the attribute of intelligence which is, according to Plato, equivalente to that of existence. From this he deriv'd the preposterous idea that the first emanation, or Intelligence, or Being, is compromis'd withe the fallen ones: ''esse (sive intellectus) est diabolus''. Being is thus always torn, in perpetual strife, between Satan and the Lord's angels. The Kabbalah, the Magyar claim'd, is the only one capable of discerning the two sides, and therefore delivering us from the grasp of Being towards Union to the One and Only God, for it alone can accesse His angels through His Word and climbe to the mystical Presence of God.}}
Scholarly interest in his idiosyncratic mysticism has only recently begun to emerge. Speculation regarding Czipleá's [[Hermeticism|Hermetic]] and Kabbalistic sources ranges from [[John Dee]], [[Pico della Mirandola]] and [[Johann Reuchlin]], while attention has been drawn to his possible influence on the [[Cambridge Platonists]] and [[Metaphysical Poets]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cziplea, Adorjan}} [[Category:Christian Kabbalah| Kabbalah]] [[Category:1639 births]] [[Category:1664 deaths]] [[Category:Kabbalists]] [[Category:Christian Kabbalists]]

{{Other uses|Aethra (Greek mythology)}} [[File:Laurent de la La Hyre 002.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Laurent%20de%20la%20La%20Hyre%20002.jpg|thumb|Theseus and Aethra, by Laurent de La Hire (1606-1656)]]In [[Greek mythology]], '''Aethra''' or '''Aithra''' ({{lang-grc|Αἴθρα}}, {{IPA-el|ǎi̯tʰra|pron}}, {{IPAc-en|lang|ˈ|iː|θ|r|ə|}}, the "bright sky"<ref>[[Robert Graves]], ''The Greek Myths'', (1955; 1960) index, ''s.v.'' "Aethra".</ref>) was a daughter of King [[Pittheus]] of [[Troezen]] and sister of [[Henioche]]. She was the mother of [[Theseus]] (his father was the [[Kings of Athens|king]] [[Aegeus]] of [[Athens]], or in some versions, [[Poseidon]]) and of [[Clymene (mythology)|Clymene]] (by [[Hippalces]]).<ref>[[Scholia]] on ''Iliad'', 3. 144; [[Dictys Cretensis]]. ''Journal of the Trojan War, Book 6.2''</ref> Aethra was also called '''Pittheis''' after her father Pittheus.<ref>[[Ovid]]. ''[[Heroides]], 10.31''.</ref>
== Mythology == === Early life === [[Bellerophon]] came to Troezen to ask Aethra's father, Pittheus for the maiden's hand in marriage, but the hero was banished from [[Corinth]] before the nuptials took place.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]]. ''Description of Greece, 2.31.12''</ref>
King Aegeus who was childless with his previous marriages went to Troezen, a city southwest of Athens that had as its patrons [[Athena]] and Poseidon. Here Pittheus got Aegeus drunk on unmixed wine and put him to bed with his daughter. Following the instructions of Athena in a dream, she left the sleeping Aegeus and waded across to the island of [[Sphairia]] that lay close to Troezen's shore. There she poured a [[libation]] to Sphairos, [[Pelops]]' charioteer, and was raped by Poseidon in the night. Aethra was therefore impregnated by both Aegeus<ref>[[Plutarch]]. ''Theseus, 3''; [[Gaius Julius Hyginus|Hyginus]]. ''Fabulae, 14''</ref> and Poseidon<ref>[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Pseudo-Apollodorus]]''. Bibliotheca, 3.15.7;'' [[Gaius Julius Hyginus|Hyginus]]''. Fabulae, 37;'' [[Bacchylides]]. ''Dithyrambs, 3.34''</ref> in the process. According to [[Plutarch]], her father spread this report merely that Theseus might be regarded as the son of Poseidon, who was much revered at Troezen.<ref>[[Plutarch]]. ''Theseus, 6''</ref> This opinion, however, is nothing else but an attempt to strip the genuine story of its marvels. [[File:Demophon_Aithra_Staatliche_Antikensammlungen_2687.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Demophon_Aithra_Staatliche_Antikensammlungen_2687.jpg|right|thumb| * [[Demophon (King of Athens)|Demophon]] (?) freeing Aethra, [[Attica|Attic]] white-ground [[Kylix (drinking cup)|kylix]], 470–460 BC, [[Staatliche Antikensammlungen]] (Inv. 2687). ]]Aethra, later on dedicated in the island of Sphairia a temple to Athena Apaturia (the Deceitful), and called the island Hiera instead of Sphaeria, and also introduced among the maidens of Troezen the custom of dedicating their girdles to Athena Apaturia on the day of their marriage.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]]. ''Description of Greece, 2.33.11''</ref> At a later time, when Aethra was thus doubly pregnant, Aegeus decided to go back to Athens. Before leaving, he covered his sandals, shield and sword under a huge rock, that served as a primitive altar to Strong [[Zeus]], and told her that when their son would grow up, he should move the rock and bring his weapons back. Aethra did as she was told, and Theseus, recovering the weapons that were his birthright, grew to be a great hero, killing the [[Minotaur]], among other adventures.
=== Later adventures === Later, when Theseus kidnapped [[Helen of Troy|Helen]], he gave her to Aethra for safekeeping. Helen's brothers, the [[Dioscuri]], took Helen back and kidnapped Aethra to [[Sparta|Lacedaemon]] in revenge. There she became a slave of Helen with whom she went to [[Troy]] and remained there until found by her grandson, [[Acamas]].<ref>Plutarch. ''Theseus, 34;'' [[Homer]]. ''[[Iliad]], 3.144;'' [[Dio Chrysostom]]. ''Speeches, [http://94.70.254.130:8080/topostextnew/work.php?work_id=197#11.59 11.59]''</ref> At the taking of [[Troy]] she came to the camp of the Greeks, where she was recognised by her grandsons, and [[Demophon of Athens|Demophon]], one of them, asked [[Agamemnon]] to procure her liberation. Agamemnon accordingly sent a messenger to Helen to request her to give up Aethra. This was granted, and Aethra became free again.<ref>Pausanias. ''Description of Greece, 10.25.3''; [[Dictys Cretensis]]. ''Journal of the Trojan War, 5.13''</ref> According to [[Gaius Julius Hyginus|Hyginus]], she afterwards put an end to her own life from grief at the death of her sons.<ref>Hyginus. ''Fabulae, 243''</ref> The history of her bondage to Helen was represented on the celebrated chest of [[Cypselus]],<ref>Pausanias. ''Description of Greece, 4.19.1;'' [[Dio Chrysostom|Dion Chrysostom]].'' Orations, 11''</ref> and in a painting by [[Polygnotus]] in the [[Lesche]] of [[Delphi]].<ref>Pausanias. ''Description of Greece, 10.25.2.''</ref>
== Gallery == <gallery mode="packed-hover"> File:Theseus and Aithra.png|Theseus and Aethra by Sybil Tawse File:Nicolas-Guy Brenet - Aethra Showing her Son Theseus the Place Where his Father had Hidden his Arms.jpg|Aethra Showing her Son Theseus the Place Where his Father had Hidden his Arms by Nicolas-Guy Brenet (1768) File:Thésée retrouve l'épée de son père - Poussin - c1638.jpg|Thésée retrouve l'épée de son père by Nicolas Poussin & Jean Lemaire (circa 1638) File:Antonio Balestra - Theseus Discovering his Father's Sword - WGA1231.jpg|Theseus Discovering his Father's Sword by Antonio Balestra (1st half of 18th century) </gallery>
== In popular culture == With significant alterations to the character, a version of this Aethra appears (as "Aithra"), a sorceress and concubine of Poseidon, in [[Richard Strauss|Richard Strauss's]] famous opera ''[[Die ägyptische Helena]]'' (The Egyptian Helen).
== References == {{Portal|Greek mythology|||}}<references />
== Sources == * [[William Smith (lexicographer)|William Smith]]. [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology|''A Dictionary of Greek and Roman biography and mythology.'']] ''s.v. [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0104%3Aalphabetic+letter%3DA%3Aentry+group%3D8%3Aentry%3Daethra-bio-1 Aethra]''. London (1848).{{PD-notice}}

{{Infobox person | name = Akhtem Seitablayev | image = Koronatsiya Slova 2014 - 1840 (cropped).jpg | native_name = Ahtem Şevket oğlu Seitablayev | birth_date = 11 December 1972 | birth_place = [[Yangiyo‘l]], [[Uzbek SSR]] | occupation = film director
actor | years_active = 1999 – present | notable_works = ''[[Haytarma]]'' (2013)
''[[Cyborgs: Heroes Never Die]]'' (2017) }} '''Akhtem Seitablayev''' ({{Lang-crh|Ahtem Şevket oğlu Seytablayev}}; born 11 December 1972 in [[Yangiyo‘l]], [[Uzbek SSR]]) is a Crimean-Tatar actor, screenwriter, and film director based in Ukraine. He is the director of several high-profile films, including ''[[Haytarma]]'' in 2013 and ''Another's Prayer'' in 2017''.'' He has expressed opposition to the [[annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation]] and his films about the fate of several prominent Crimean Tatars have been criticized by Russian news outlets. == Early life == Seitablayev was born in 1972 in [[Yangiyo‘l]], then part of the [[Uzbek SSR]]. His parents were deported to Uzbekistan in the [[Deportation of the Crimean Tatars|Sürgün]] since Crimean Tatars were one of the ten ethnic groups to experience collective punishment of exile in the Stalin era. He attended school in Uzbekistan and remained in exile with his family until they moved back to [[Crimea]] during the [[Perestroika]] era in 1989, where he began his film career in 1992 after graduating from the Crimean Cultural Enlightenment School.{{Cite web|url=https://www.kino-teatr.ru/kino/acter/m/post/16395/bio/|title=Ахтем Сеитаблаев|website=Кино-Театр.РУ|access-date=2018-06-22}}{{Cite news|url=https://lifeactor.ru/11840-ahtem-seytablaev.html|title=Ахтем Сейтаблаев|work=Актеры - Биографии актеров - Фото актеров на Lifeactor.ru|access-date=2018-06-22|language=ru-RU}}{{Cite news|url=https://tv.ua/interview/ahtem-seitablaev-v-dni-rozhdenija-detej-ja-ne-rabotaju-87730.html|title=Ахтем Сеитаблаев: В дни рождения детей я не работаю|access-date=2018-06-22|language=ru}} == Career == From 1992 to 2004 he worked at the Simferopol State Crimean Tatar Theater, where he directed several plays including works of [[Alexander Pushkin]]. In 2005 he began working at the [[Kiev Academic Theatre of Drama and Comedy on the left-bank of Dnieper]]. In 2009 he directed his first film, ''Quartet for Two.'' In 2013 he directed the movie ''[[Haytarma]]'' (English: Return) based on the real life of [[Amet-khan Sultan]], a Crimean Tatar [[flying ace]] and twice [[Hero of the Soviet Union]] who witnessed the [[Deportation of the Crimean Tatars|Sürgün]] but managed to avoid deportation due to his father's [[Laks (Caucasus)|Lak]] ancestory and the intervention of [[Timofey Khryukin]], commander of the [[8th Air Army]]. The film was praised by the [[Kyiv Post|''Kiev Post'']] as "must-see for history enthusiasts" and criticized by ''[[Komsomolskaya Pravda]]'' for depicting the organizers of the deportation in a bad light.{{Cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/guide/movies/haytarma-the-first-crimean-tatar-movie-is-a-must-see-for-history-enthusiasts-326698.html|title='Haytarma', the first Crimean Tatar movie, is a must-see for history enthusiasts - Jul. 08, 2013|date=2013-07-08|work=KyivPost|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.kp.ru/daily/26093/2993195/|title=Почему правда о войне до сих пор ссорит нас с крымскими татарами?|last=правды»|first=Галина САПОЖНИКОВА {{!}} Сайт «Комсомольской|date=2013-06-18|work=KP.RU - сайт «Комсомольской правды»|access-date=2018-06-22|language=ru}} From 2016 to 2017 he directed [[Another's Prayer]], based on the real life of [[Saide Arifova]], a kindergarten director who saved over 80 Jewish children during the Holocaust by switching their ethnicity listing and teaching them to imitate Crimean Tatar customs and language to hide them from the [[Gestapo]]. Eventually the Nazis suspected she was involved in hiding Jewish children and tortured her, but she refused to betray any names. After the Red Army retook control of Crimea she saved them again by explaining to the [[NKVD]] that the children were Jewish, not Crimean Tatar, and hence were allowed to stay in Crimea instead of being deported to the desert. The film debuted on 18 May 2017, the anniversary of the Sürgün. Originally the film was supposed to be filmed in Crimea, but after the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation in 2014 it was decided that the filming would be done in mainland Ukraine and Georgia.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ukrinform.ru/rubric-society/2230924-v-kieve-sostoalas-premera-filma-ahtema-sejtablaeva-cuzaa-molitva.html|title=В Киеве состоялась премьера фильма Ахтема Сейтаблаева "Чужая молитва"|access-date=2018-06-22|language=ru}} == Personal life == On 29 May 2018, he released a statement in support of [[Oleg Sentsov]], a film director arrested in Russian-controlled Crimea. He is married to actress Ivanna Dyadyur, and has three children.{{Cite web|url=https://24tv.ua/ru/oleg__otec_kak_i_vy__seitablaev_prosit_trampa_pomoch_osvobodit_sencova_n977782|title=Олег – отец, как и вы, – Сеитаблаев просит Трампа помочь освободить Сенцова - 24 Канал|website=24 Канал|access-date=2018-06-22}} == References == {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seitablaiev, Akhtem}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:1+1 (TV channel) people]] [[Category:21st-century Ukrainian male actors]] [[Category:Ukrainian theatre directors]] [[Category:Ukrainian film directors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Crimean Tatar people]] [[Category:Ukrainian Muslims]]

{{Infobox person | name = Alexandre Stavisky | image = Alexandre Stavisky 1926.jpg | image_size = | caption = Alexandre Stavisky in 1926 | birth_name = | birth_date = November 20, 1886 | birth_place = Slobodka, [[Kiev Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{D-da|January 8, 1934|November 20, 1886}} | death_place = [[Chamonix]], France | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Père Lachaise Cemetery]] | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = | employer = | occupation = Financier | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = }}
'''Serge Alexandre Stavisky''' (November 20, 1886, [[Ukraine]] – January 8, 1934, [[Chamonix]]) was a French financier and [[embezzler]] whose actions created a political scandal that became known as the [[Stavisky Affair]].<ref>Paul Jankowski, ''Stavisky - A Confidence Man in the Republic of Virtue'', (2002)</ref><ref>David Clay Large, ''Between Two Fires: Europes Path in the 1930s'' (W.W.Norton: 1990) pp 24-58</ref>
==Early life== Alexandre Stavisky was a [[Polish Jew]]<ref>{{cite news|author=Kathy Warnes|title=The Stavisky Affair - Sasha the Suave Scammer|url=https://historybecauseitshere.weebly.com/the-stavisky-affair---sasha-the-suave-scammer.html|newspaper=historybecauseitshere|date=|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> born in modern-day [[Ukraine]] whose Russian parents had moved to France.<ref>Paul Jankowski, ''Stavisky – A Confidence Man in the Republic of Virtue'' (2002)</ref>
==Career== Stavisky tried various professions, working as a café singer, as a nightclub manager, as a worker in a soup factory, and as the operator of a gambling den. He received French citizenship in 1910. In the 1930s he managed municipal pawnshops in Bayonne but also moved in financial circles. He sold lots of worthless bonds and financed his "hockshop" on the surety of what he called the emeralds of the late Empress of Germany — which later turned out to be glass. In 1927, Stavisky was put on trial for fraud for the first time, charged with a 6 million pound fraud. However, the trial was postponed again and again, and he was granted bail 19 times.
Faced with exposure in December 1933, Stavisky fled. On 8 January 1934, the police found him in a [[Chamonix]] chalet dying from two gunshot wounds to the head. Surgeons struggled to save him but he died early in the hours of January 9.<ref>Daily Mirror headline, January 9, 1934,</ref> Officially, Stavisky committed suicide, but historians generally agree he was murdered to keep him silent.
In the aftermath there were many riots on the streets of Paris, resulting in 250 arrests on January 10 as news of government involvement in the financial scandal broke.<ref>Daily Mirror headline January 10, 1934</ref> The French premier [[Camille Chautemps]] was forced to resign owing to the number of ministers wrapped up in the affair, and rumours that he had ordered Stavisky's assassination. An official public enquiry was ordered into the affair. Shortly before it began a senior judge, Albert Prince, who was due to be a witness, was found murdered on a railway line near Dijon, having been tricked to go there from Paris by means of a bogus telegram claiming his mother was very ill.<ref>Daily Mirror headline, 22nd February 1934</ref>
==Death and legacy== Stavisky died on January 8, 1934, [[Chamonix]]. He was buried in [[Père Lachaise Cemetery]].
In ''[[Forces occultes]]'', a film commissioned in 1942 by the "Propaganda Abteilung", a delegation of [[Nazi Germany]]'s propaganda ministry within [[German occupation of France during World War II|occupied France]], Stavisky was presented as both a [[Freemason]] and a crook. In 1974, film director [[Alain Resnais]] told the story in the film ''[[Stavisky]]...'' that featured [[Jean-Paul Belmondo]] in the title role and [[Anny Dupérey]] as his wife Arlette.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * [[Paul Jankowski]], ''Stavisky - A Confidence Man in the Republic of Virtue'', (2002) {{ISBN|0-8014-3959-0}} * Large, David Clay, ''Between Two Fires: Europes Path in the 1930s'' (W.W.Norton: 1990) pp 24–58, a scholarly account
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stavisky, Alexandre}} [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1934 deaths]] [[Category:People from Kiev Governorate]] [[Category:Ukrainian Jews]] [[Category:French people of Ukrainian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:French financiers]] [[Category:20th-century Jews]] [[Category:20th-century French criminals]] [[Category:Criminals who committed suicide]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in France]] [[Category:Burials at Père Lachaise Cemetery]]

{{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] |image = |caption = |name = Alison M. Jaggar |birth_name = Alison Mary Hayes |birth_date = September 23, 1942 |birth_place = [[Sheffield]], England, United Kingdom |school_tradition = [[Feminist philosophy]], [[Feminist studies]] |main_interests = [[Social philosophy]], [[moral philosophy]], [[political philosophy]] |notable_ideas = |institutions = [[University of Colorado, Boulder]], [[University of Oslo]], [[SUNY Buffalo]], [[Miami University]], the [[University of Cincinnati]], the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]], the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], [[Rutgers University]], [[Victoria University of Wellington]] |influences = |influenced = |signature = }} '''Alison Mary Jaggar''' (born September 23, 1942)<ref name="bloomsbury-bio">{{cite web|last1=Shook|first1=John R.|title=The Bloomsbury Encyclopedia of Philosophers in America: From 1600 to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XjM0CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA499&lpg=PA499&dq=alison+jaggar+born+in&source=bl&ots=ypqTJ9-rMj&sig=QARSIDGnQLb5Dfxuk0KJeG5Uuks&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZ6cvGsavOAhUh_IMKHbLfDaY4ChDoAQgkMAM#v=onepage&q=alison%20jaggar%20born%20in&f=false|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|accessdate=5 August 2016|pages=499–500|date=February 11, 2016}}</ref> is an American [[feminist]] [[philosopher]] born in England. She is currently College Professor of Distinction in the Philosophy and Women and Gender Studies departments at the [[University of Colorado, Boulder]]<ref name=biog>{{cite web|title=Philosophy Department, University of California, Boulder |url=http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/fac_jaggar.shtml |publisher=University of Colorado, Boulder |accessdate=18 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902104914/http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/fac_jaggar.shtml |archivedate=2 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> and Distinguished Research Professor at the [[University of Birmingham]] in the United Kingdom. She was one of the first people to introduce feminist concerns in to philosophy.<ref name=apacsw>{{cite web|last=DeSautels|first=Peggy|title=Alison Jaggar: April 2013|url=http://www.apaonlinecsw.org/home/woman_philosopher/alisonjaggarapril2013|work=Highlighted Philosophers|publisher=American Philosophical Association|accessdate=18 August 2013}}</ref>
==Education and career== Born in [[Sheffield]], England,<ref name="bloomsbury-bio"/> Jaggar earned a bachelor's degree in philosophy at [[Bedford College, London|Bedford College, University of London]] in 1964<ref name=cv>{{cite web|title=Curriculum Vitae |url=http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/cv_jaggar.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225184106/http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/cv_jaggar.pdf |archivedate=2014-02-25 |df= }}</ref> and a master's degree in philosophy from the [[University of Edinburgh]] in 1967. She completed her doctorate in philosophy from the [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|State University of New York (SUNY), Buffalo]] in 1970.<ref name=cv/>
During her career, Jaggar has held appointments at SUNY Buffalo, [[Miami University]], the [[University of Cincinnati]], the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]], the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], [[Rutgers University]], [[Victoria University of Wellington]], the [[University of Oslo]], and the [[University of Birmingham]].<ref name=cv/><ref name="birmingham_bio"/> From 1994–1997, she was director of the Women’s Studies department at the University of Colorado at Boulder. She later served as Graduate Director and Associate Chair of the Philosophy department at the university from 2004–2008.<ref name=cv/> From 2007–2014, she worked as a Research Coordinator at the Centre for the Study of Mind in Nature at the [[University of Oslo]] in Norway.<ref name=biog/><ref name=cv/>
A founding member of the [[Society for Women in Philosophy]], she was instrumental in the creation of the field of feminist studies, and taught what she believes to have been the first feminist philosophy course ever offered.<ref name=apacsw/> A co-founder of ''[[Hypatia (journal)|Hypatia: A Journal of Feminist Philosophy]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Hypatia Honor Rolll|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/|publisher=Hypatia|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> Jaggar was a member of the editorial board from 1983–2009 and Associate Editor from 2006–2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hypatia Honor Roll|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/honor_roll_2013.html|publisher=Hypatia|accessdate=5 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140412013146/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/honor_roll_2013.html|archive-date=2014-04-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> She chaired the [[American Philosophical Association]] (APA) Committee on the Status of Women from 1986–1991<ref name="cv" /> and served as co-president of the [[North American Society for Social Philosophy]] from 1995–1997.<ref name="cv" />
Jaggar has been awarded research fellowships from the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]], the [[Rockefeller Foundation]], [[American Association of University Women]] (AAUW), the [[University of Edinburgh]], the [[Norwegian Research Council]] and the [[Australian Research Council]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Measuring Gendered Poverty: Methodology and Morality|url=http://genderstudies.nd.edu/events/2015/02/13/32566-measuring-gendered-poverty-methodology-and-morality/|publisher=University of Notre Dame|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> She has served on the editorial boards of ''[[Solidarity (U.S.)|Against the Current]]'', ''[[Hypatia (journal)|Hypatia: A Journal of Feminist Philosophy]]'', ''[[Radical Philosophy Review]]'', ''Asian Journal of Women’s Studies'', ''[[Journal of Social Philosophy]]'', ''Studies in Feminist Philosophy'', ''International Journal of Feminist Bioethics'', and ''Journal of International Critical Thought''.<ref name=cv/>
Jaggar was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2017.<ref>https://www.amacad.org/content/members/newFellows.aspx?s=c</ref>
==Philosophical work== Jaggar studies gender and [[globalization]] using [[normative]], [[methodological]], and [[epistemological]] perspectives. She has published several articles identifying "how global institutions and policies interact with local practices to create gendered cycles of vulnerability and exploitation" and its influence on policy. She has helped develop a new poverty measure that evaluates how gender influences and is impacted by poverty.<ref name="birmingham_bio">{{cite web|title=Professor Alison M. Jaggar B.A. Hons. (Bedford College, London), M. Litt. (Edinburgh), Ph.D. (Buffalo)|url=http://www.birmingham.ac.uk/staff/profiles/philosophy/jaggar-alison.aspx|publisher=University of Birmingham|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref>
Her work has been hugely influential,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tolmach Lakoff|first1=Robin|title=Language and Woman's Place: Text and Commentaries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E89hnoy89GUC&pg=PT188&lpg=PT188&dq=jaggar+influential&source=bl&ots=kDzQ6CLzAt&sig=eOH8X401AYNPjT9iO7KqrwrAG98&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjp5Mz2vavOAhVL2oMKHbhvD2cQ6AEINzAE#v=onepage&q=jaggar%20influential&f=false|publisher=Oxford University Press,|accessdate=6 August 2016|date=July 22, 2004}}</ref> with [[Rosemarie Tong]] and [[Nancy Williams]] suggesting in the ''[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' that "If ethics is about human beings' liberation, then Alison Jaggar's summary of the fourfold function of feminist ethics cannot be improved upon in any significant way"<ref name=femeth>{{cite web|last=Rosemarie Tong|first=Nancy Williams|title=Feminist Ethics|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/feminism-ethics/|work=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|publisher=Stanford|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> and Jaggar's texts being considered classics.<ref name=fempolphi>{{cite web|last=McAfee|first=Noelle|title=Feminist Political Philosophy|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/feminism-political/|work=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|publisher=Stanford|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>
==Publications== Jaggar has authored a large number of widely cited papers, most notably "Love and knowledge: Emotion in feminist epistemology", published in 1989 and cited by at least 800 other peer-reviewed papers as of August 2013. Jaggar has also acted as co-editor for the first issue of [[Telos (journal)|''Telos'']], and was a co-founder and associate editor of ''[[Hypatia (journal)|Hypatia: A Journal of Feminist Philosophy]]'' from 2006 to 2008.<ref name=cv/>
Jaggar has written one book, edited seven books, and co-authored two: * {{cite book | last1 = Jaggar | first1 = Alison | last2 = Rothenberg | first2 = Paula | title = Feminist frameworks: alternative theoretical accounts of the relations between women and men | publisher = McGraw-Hill | location = New York | year = 1978 | isbn = 9780070322509 }} * {{cite book | last = Jaggar | first = Alison | title = Feminist politics and human nature | publisher = Rowman & Allanheld | location = Totowa, New Jersey | year = 1983 | isbn = 9780710806536 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Jaggar | first1 = Alison | last2 = Bordo | first2 = Susan R. | title = Gender/body/knowledge: feminist reconstructions of being and knowing | publisher = Rutgers University Press | location = New Brunswick, New Jersey | year = 1989 | isbn = 9780813513799 }} * {{cite book | last = Jaggar | first = Alison | title = Living with contradictions: controversies in feminist social ethics | publisher = Westview Press | location = Boulder, Colorado | year = 1994 | isbn = 9780813317762 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Jaggar | first1 = Alison | last2 = Sterba | first2 = James P. | last3 = Gould | first3 = Carol C. | last4 = Solomon | first4 = Robert C. | last5 = Machan | first5 = Tibor R. | last6 = Galstone | first6 = William A. | last7 = Fisk | first7 = Milton | title = Morality and social justice: point/counterpoint | publisher = Rowman & Littlefield Publishers | location = Lanham, Maryland | year = 1995 | isbn = 9780847679782 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Jaggar | first1 = Alison | last2 = Young | first2 = Iris Marion | author-link2 = Iris Marion Young | title = A companion to feminist philosophy | publisher = Blackwell | location = Malden, Massachusetts | year = 2000 | isbn = 9780631227649 }} * {{citation | last = Jaggar | first = Alison | contribution = Arenas of citizenship: civil society, the state and the global order | editor-last = Friedman | editor-first = Marilyn | editor-link = Marilyn Friedman | title = Women and citizenship | pages = 91–110 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | series = Studies in Feminist Philosophy | year = 2005 | isbn = 9780195175356 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{cite book | last = Jaggar | first = Alison | title = Just methods: an interdisciplinary feminist reader | publisher = Paradigm Publishers | location = Boulder, Colorado | year = 2008 | isbn = 9781594512032 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Jaggar | first1 = Alison | last2 = Tooley | first2 = Michael | last3 = Wolfe-Devine | first3 = Celia | last4 = Devine | first4 = Philip E. | title = Abortion: three perspectives | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York | year = 2009 | isbn = 9780195380279 }} * {{cite book | last = Jaggar | first = Alison | title = Thomas Pogge and his critics | publisher = Polity | location = Cambridge Malden, Massachusetts | year = 2010 | isbn = 9780745642581 }} * {{cite book | last = Jaggar | first = Alison | title = Gender and global justice | publisher = Polity | location = Cambridge, UK Malden, Massachusetts | year = 2014 | isbn = 9780745663760 }} * {{Cite journal | last = Jaggar | first = Alison M. | title = On Susan Moller Okin's "Reason and feeling in thinking about justice" | journal = [[Ethics (journal)|Ethics]] | volume = 125 | issue = 4 | pages = 1127–1131 | publisher = [[Chicago University Press|Chicago Journals]] via [[JSTOR]] | doi = 10.1086/680878 | jstor = 10.1086/680878 | date = July 2015 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1086/680878 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}
As of August 2013, ''Feminist Politics and Human Nature'' had been cited by more than 2,000 peer-reviewed papers.

{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2008}} {{Infobox person |image =Amod_Cassimjee.jpg |image_size = 200px |alt = | name = Amod Cassimjee | birth_name = Amod Cassimjee | birth_date = 1871 | birth_place = [[Surat]], India | death_date = 16 May 1951 (aged 80) | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = Mountain Rise Cemetery, [[Pietermaritzburg]], South Africa | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Pietermaritzburg]], South Africa | nationality = Indian | other_names = | known_for = Businessman, Industrialist | education = | employer = | occupation = Businessman | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = Ayesha Cassimjee
Hawa Bibi Cassimjee | partner = | children = [[Ismail Amod Cassimjee]]
Khatija Cassimjee
Fathima Cassimjee
Ayesha Cassimjee | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Amod Cassimjee''' was born and educated in [[Surat]], India. He arrived in South Africa in 1895 and settled in [[Pietermaritzburg]].{{cite web |url=http://scnc.ukzn.ac.za/doc/B/Who/Whos_Who_1936_7/Whos_Who_1936_37_pt5_A_Z_Mixed.pdf |title=South African Who's Who 1936 |publisher= |accessdate=19 April 2011}}{{cite web| url=http://scnc.ukzn.ac.za/doc/B/Who/Whos_Who_1972/Southern_Africa_Indian_Who_Who_1971-1972_pt3_BOD_D.pdf | title=Southern Africa Indian Who's Who 1971-2 | accessdate = 1 June 2013}} ==Business== He joined his brother Suleman, trading as Suleman Cassimjee & Co. for a few years. Amod then established his first business in [[Kranskop]]. Amod later returned to [[Pietermaritzburg]] and entered into partnership as Amod Mahomed & Co. The partnership was dissolved in 1913 and Amod Cassimjee assumed his sole ownership of the business and traded under his own name. It was one of the best known firms in Upper Church Street in the African trade with a European department boasting a large clientele. Also entered the Shoe Manufacturing Field. One of the most colourful personalities in the City and popularly known by a wide African custom as "Khandalemvu". He was interested in all Indian activities and as a Grand Old man laid the foundation stone of the Mohammedian Oriental School. Attached to the Upper Church Street Mosque. Amod and [[Suleman Cassimjee]] formed a company called Suleman Cassimjee & Co. The business was started in Winterton, [[Kwa-Zulu Natal]]. [[Mahomed Cassimjee]] and Amod joined their brother in the company [[Suleman Cassimjee & Co]]. for a few years.{{cite web |title=Natal Museum, Pietermaritzburg |url=http://www.nmsa.org.za/ |publisher= |accessdate=19 April 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.avovision.co.za/2007/11/13/classrooms-in-the-shade-shanthee-falls-hopelessly-in-love/ |title=Shantee Falls hopelessly in Love |publisher= |accessdate=19 April 2011}} ==Personal and community leadership== Amod Cassimjee was keenly interested in the welfare of the [[Muslims]] as well as the Indian community as a whole. He laid the foundation for the establishment of the Muhammadan Oriental School (now Government-aided). He was ever prepared to assist all movements directed for the good of the community.{{cite book |url=http://scnc.ukzn.ac.za/doc/B/Who/Whos_Who_1940/Whos_Who_1940_pt2_A_K.pdf |title=South African Who's who 1940 |accessdate=19 April 2011}} ==Death== Amod Cassimjee died on 16 May 1951 at the age of 80. He was buried in the Mountain Rise Cemetery in [[Pietermaritzburg]], South Africa. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cassimjee, Amod}} [[Category:Indian expatriates in South Africa]] [[Category:Gujarati people]] [[Category:People of British India]] [[Category:1871 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:Indian Muslims]]

{{Infobox person | name = Ashkan Soltani | image = Ashkan Soltani (7250137444).jpg | image_size = 250px | residence = [[Washington, DC]], United States | alma_mater = *[[University of California, Berkeley]] | occupation = Chief Technologist, Federal Trade Commission; Privacy and security researcher | website = [http://www.ashkansoltani.org/ www.ashkansoltani.org/] }}
'''Ashkan Soltani''' was the Chief Technologist of the [[Federal Trade Commission]].<ref name=FTC_Announcement>{{cite web|title=Federal Trade Commission Appoints Ashkan Soltani as Chief Technologist|url=http://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2014/10/federal-trade-commission-appoints-ashkan-soltani-chief|publisher=Federal Trade Commission|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref> He was previously an independent privacy and security researcher, based in [[Washington, DC]].
Between 2010 and 2011, he worked for the [[United States|US]] Federal Trade Commission as a staff technologist in the Division of Privacy and Identity Protection, where he assisted with the investigations of [[Google]] and [[Facebook]]. He has also worked as the primary technical consultant to the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'''s What They Know series investigating online privacy.
In 2011, he testified at two different hearings held by US [[United States Senate|Senate]] committees focused on privacy related matters. [[Julia Angwin]], in her 2014 book ''Dragnet Nation'', describes Soltani as 'the leading technical expert on [[ad tracking]] technology'.<ref>{{cite book |last=Angwin |first=Julia |date=2014 |title=Dragnet Nation |url=https://www.amazon.com/Dragnet-Nation-Security-Relentless-Surveillance/dp/0805098070 |location=New York, NY |publisher=Times Books, Henry Holt & Company |pages=178 |isbn=978-0805098075}}</ref> He was part of the team at ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that shared the 2014 [[Pulitzer Prize for Public Service]] with ''[[Guardian US|The Guardian US]]'' for their coverage of the [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)|disclosures]] about surveillance done by the US [[National Security Agency]].<ref name=WP12>{{cite news|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Craig Timberg |author3=Steven Rich |last-author-amp=yes |title=Files show NSA targeted Tor encrypted network|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/files/2014/public-service/washpost/12washpostnsa2014.pdf|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=5 October 2013}} (Contributors: Ashkan Soltani and Julie Tate)</ref><ref name=WP13>{{cite news|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani |lastauthoramp=yes |title=NSA collects millions of e-mail address books globally|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/files/2014/public-service/washpost/13washpostnsa2014.pdf|accessdate=16 April 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=15 October 2013}}</ref><ref name=WP14>{{cite news|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani |lastauthoramp=yes |title=NSA taps Yahoo, Google links|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/files/2014/public-service/washpost/14washpostnsa2014.pdf|accessdate=16 April 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=31 October 2013}}</ref><ref name=WP16>{{cite news|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani |lastauthoramp=yes |title=NSA tracking cellphone locations worldwide, Snowden documents show|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/files/2014/public-service/washpost/16washpostnsa2014.pdf|accessdate=16 April 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=4 December 2013}}</ref>
==Flash cookie research==
Soltani's first high-profile research project was a 2009 study, supported by the [[National Science Foundation|National Science Foundation's]] [http://www.truststc.org/ Team for Research in Ubiquitous Secure Computing], documenting the use of [[zombie cookies|zombie]] Flash cookies by several online advertising networks.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wired.com/business/2009/08/you-deleted-your-cookies-think-again/ | title=You Deleted Your Cookies? Think Again | accessdate=2013-01-21 | last=Singel| first=Ryan | date=2009-08-10 | work=Wired News}}</ref> Soltani and his colleagues at Berkeley revealed that websites were recreating tracking cookies after consumers deleted them by storing the unique tracking identifiers in Flash cookies, which were not automatically deleted when consumers cleared their browser cookies.<ref>Soltani, Ashkan; Canty, Shannon; Mayo, Quentin; Thomas, Lauren and Hoofnagle, Chris Jay, "Flash Cookies and Privacy" (August 10, 2009). Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1446862</ref>
After the publication of Soltani's research, class action law firms filed suit against several advertising networks and websites. Quantcast, Clearspring and VideoEgg collectively agreed to pay a total of $3.4 million to settle the lawsuits.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/162977/metacafe-promises-not-to-use-flash-cookies-for-tra.html | title=Metacafe Promises Not To Use Flash Cookies For Tracking | accessdate=2013-01-21 | last=Davis| first=Wendy | date=2011-11-23 | work=MediaPost New}}</ref>
==ETag tracking research==
In 2011, Soltani and Berkeley law professor Chris Hoofnagle published a follow-up study, documenting the use of web browser cache [[HTTP ETag|ETags]] to store persistent identifiers.<ref>Ayenson, Mika, Wambach, Dietrich James, Soltani, Ashkan, Good, Nathan and Hoofnagle, Chris Jay, Flash Cookies and Privacy II: Now with HTML5 and ETag Respawning (July 29, 2011). Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1898390</ref> As with the case of Flash cookies, the identifiers stored in the ETags persisted even after consumers deleted their browser cookies.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wired.com/business/2011/07/undeletable-cookie/ | title=Researchers Expose Cunning Online Tracking Service That Can’t Be Dodged | accessdate=2013-01-21 | last=Singel| first=Ryan | date=2011-07-29 | work=Wired News}}</ref> The ETag tracking issue caught the attention of several members of [[United States Congress|Congress]], who wrote to the Federal Trade Commission in September 2011 and urged the agency to investigate the use of advanced tracking technologies as a potentially unfair or deceptive business practice.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2011/09/congressmen-blast-supercookies-as-privacy-menace/ | title= Congressmen blast "supercookies" as privacy menace | accessdate=2013-01-21 | last=Lee| first=Timothy B. | date=2011-09-27 | work=Ars Technica}}</ref>
Several companies performing ETag based tracking that were identified by the research team were subsequently sued by class action lawyers. In January 2013, KISSmetrics, an online advertising network, settled its ETag related lawsuit for $500,000.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/191409/kissmetrics-finalizes-supercookies-settlement.html | title=KISSmetrics Finalizes Supercookies Settlement | accessdate=2013-01-18 | last=Davis| first=Wendy | date=2013-01-23 | work=MediaPost New}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
