{{pp-semi-indef}} {{Use British English|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Duncan Bannatyne
[[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] | image = Duncan Bannatyne in Felixstowe 2009.jpg | caption = Bannatyne in [[Felixstowe]], 2009 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1949|2|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Clydebank]], [[Scotland]] | spouse = Nigora Whitehorn (m. 2017)
Joanne McCue (m. 2006-2012)
Gail Brodie (m. 1983) | children = 6 | occupation = [[Entrepreneurship|Entrepreneur]], [[investor]], [[television presenter]], [[Philanthropy|philanthropist]] | known_for = ''[[Dragons' Den (UK)|Dragons' Den]]'' | networth = {{gain}} {{GBP|280 million|link=yes}} | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''Duncan Walker Bannatyne''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (born 2 February 1949),{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/feb/18/broadcasting.comment|title=Duncan Bannatyne interview|last=Barber|first=Lynn|date=18 February 2007|work=[[The Observer]]|accessdate=10 November 2008|location=London}} is a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]], [[Philanthropy|philanthropist]] and author. His business interests include hotels, health clubs, spas, media, TV, and property. He is most famous for his appearance as a [[business angel]] on the [[BBC]] programme ''[[Dragons' Den (UK)|Dragons' Den]]''. He was appointed an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] for his contribution to charity. He has written seven books. ==Early life== Bannatyne was born in [[Dalmuir]] west of [[Glasgow]]. His father Bill had served in the [[Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders]] in [[World War II]] and worked on the [[Burma Railway]] after being captured by the Japanese following the [[Battle of Singapore|Fall of Singapore]], he then worked in the foundry at the Clydebank [[Singer Corporation|Singer]] plant. As a child Duncan lived in one room with his parents and siblings in a large house shared with six other families. He attended Dalmuir Primary School where he displayed a talent for arithmetic and won a place at [[Clydebank High School]] after passing the [[Eleven plus exam]]. Most pupils owned a bicycle so he resolved to earn the money to buy one for himself. The local newsagent was not interested in employing him so she challenged him to find 100 new customers in return for a paper round. He called her bluff by returning with 100 names, but later reflected that it would have been more entrepreneurial to have sold the list. He only enjoyed [[Physical education|PE]] and woodwork at the High School and left at 15 without any qualifications.{{cite book|date=3 September 2007|author=Duncan Bannatyne|isbn=0-7528-8189-2|title=Anyone Can Do It:My Story|publisher=Orion Publishing Group}} In 1964, after a few weeks working for a local [[cabinet-maker]] he joined the [[Royal Navy]], initially enlisting for twelve years as a junior second class engineering mechanic ([[Stoker (occupation)|stoker]]) at [[RNTE Shotley]] near [[Ipswich]], better known as the boys' training establishment HMS ''Ganges''. He served in the Navy for several years including a spell on the aircraft carrier HMS ''[[HMS Eagle (R05)|Eagle]],'' before throwing an officer off a boat landing jetty in Scotland and receiving a [[dishonourable discharge]]. In his autobiography he claims this was in part a reaction to this officer's abuse of his authority, in part a dare by his shipmates and in part a way of getting out of the Navy, with which he had become disillusioned. Bannatyne was nineteen when this happened. After the incident he had to serve nine months in [[Colchester]] military detention centre. He later spent ten days in Glasgow's [[Barlinnie prison]] for not paying a [[pound sterling|£]]10 fine in relation to a charge of [[breach of the peace]] and [[resisting arrest]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sundayherald.com/life/people/display.var.2442236.0.0.php |title=In the Dragons' Den with God |publisher=Sunday Herald |date=6 September 2008 |accessdate=23 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206120928/http://www.sundayherald.com/life/people/display.var.2442236.0.0.php |archivedate=6 December 2008 }}{{cite web|title=Would I Lie To You Series 1 Episode 1|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C8BygaZXsj4&t=8m58s}} ==Career== Bannatyne spent his twenties moving from one job to another. Upon his return to Clydebank he trained as an agricultural vehicle fitter and then travelled around the country repairing tractors. He lived on the island of [[Jersey]] for four years from 1974 where he gained an [[Large goods vehicle|HGV]] licence and earned a living through several jobs including deckchair attendant, ice cream seller and hospital porter. He also [[surfing|surfed]], partied and met his first wife on the island. With Jersey's difficult business climate for outsiders, at age 29, Bannatyne and his wife moved to [[Stockton-on-Tees]] in [[North East England]]. He has stated that he was poor and did not have a bank account until the age of 30.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/tv/programmes/genres/entertainment/schedules/2010/07/14 Direct quote from Bannatyne from ''Dragon's Den'', 14 July 2010]. BBC. Retrieved on 28 March 2012. His business career began almost immediately after his move to [[Stockton-on-Tees]] with an ice cream van purchased for £450.[http://www.bannatyne.co.uk/about-duncan About Duncan - The Bannatyne Group] He soon expanded by buying more vans during the period of the [[Glasgow Ice Cream Wars]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2900560/Business-profile-Duncan-is-ready-for-his-close-up.html|title=Business profile: Duncan is ready for his close-up|date=28 November 2004|accessdate=3 August 2011|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph}} He sold the business for £28,000, founding a [[nursing home]] business called Quality Care Homes which he then sold for £26 million in 1997 and children's nursery chain Just Learning for £12 million.{{cite news |url=http://www.darlingtonandstocktontimes.co.uk/leisure/weekendtimes/feature/display.var.1004496.0.driven_restless_and_a_bit_arrogant_but_definitely_not_the_retiring_kind.php|title=Driven Restless And A Bit Arrogant But Definitely Not The Retiring Kind |work=Darlington and Stockton Times |date=4 November 2006 |accessdate=23 March 2010}} The Just Learning [[chief executive]] during the 1992–97 period was Conservative MP [[Michael Fallon]].{{cite web |first=Tiffany |last=Holland|url=http://www.retail-week.com/profile-michael-fallon-minister-for-business/5040550.article|title=Profile: Michael Fallon, Minister for business|publisher=retail-week.com |date=14 September 2012 |accessdate=10 October 2012}} Bannatyne has since expanded into health clubs, with the Bannatyne Health Club & Spa chain to his name, and also hotels and property. He acquired 26 health clubs from [[Hilton Hotels]] in August 2006 at a price of £92 million. The Bannatyne Group is now the largest independent chain of health clubs in the United Kingdom with 71 sites. The business currently (June 2018) has 46 spas with plans for more, including at its first Northern Ireland-based health club in Belfast {{Cite news|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/northern-ireland/dragons-dens-duncan-bannatyne-opening-gym-in-northern-ireland-36361757.html|title=Dragon's Den's Duncan Bannatyne opening gym in Northern Ireland|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} and it operates 4 hotels. His wealth as of 2018, was estimated at £280 million by the [[Sunday Times Rich List 2018|Sunday Times Rich List]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/public/richlist/article629845.ece|title=The wealthiest in film and TV|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=20 May 2011|accessdate=1 November 2011|last=Coxon|first=Ian|location=London}} Bannatyne has written seven books: ''Anyone Can Do It'', ''Wake Up and Change Your Life'', ''How to be Smart With Your Money'', ''How to be Smart With Your Time'', ''43 Mistakes Businesses Make'', ''37 Questions Everyone in Business Needs to Answer'', and ''Riding The Storm''. ===Television=== From 2005 until 2015, Duncan was a Dragon on the BBC television series ''[[Dragons' Den (UK TV series)|Dragons' Den]]''. During his time on the show he invested in 36 businesses. In 2015, Bannatyne took part in the [[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK series 15)|fifteenth series]] of ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK TV series)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]''. His fee for taking part in the show was donated to the [[Operation Smile]] charity. ===Charity works=== Bannatyne received his OBE partly in recognition for his work with charities such as [[Mary's meals]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-12373390 Mary's Meals charity 'feeding 500,000 children a day' - 5 February 2011] He has funded several projects over a ten-year period in Romania, including Casa Bannatyne in [[Târgu-Mureş]], a [[hospice]] for orphans with [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]] in which he invested £80,000. In March 2008, he established the Bannatyne Charitable Trust with a personal injection of £1,000,000.{{cite web |first=Sylvia |last=Morris |url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/meandmymoney/article-1630415/Duncan-Bannatyne-Me--money.html |title=Duncan Bannatyne: Me & my money |work=thisismoney.co.uk|date=23 April 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2012}} On 19 May 2008, Bannatyne added his support to the launch of the [[Geared for Giving]] Campaign at the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] to encourage UK business leaders to set up and promote a Workplace Giving scheme to benefit UK registered charities with tax effective donations through employees' pay. He then helped to promote [[Clydesdale Bank]]'s and [[Yorkshire Bank]]'s efforts to promote the programme through ATM ([[Automated Teller Machine]]) rolls. "They are really going for it, over 20 per cent of their employees are giving money through this system", Bannatyne says.{{cite news |first=David |last=Mills |url=https://www.theguardian.com/voluntary-sector-network/2010/dec/16/duncan-bannatyne-geared-for-giving |title=A charitable dragon: Why Duncan Bannatyne is geared for giving |work=The Guardian |date=16 December 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2012 |location=London}} On 29 August 2008, Bannatyne appeared on television programme ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'', raising £20,000 for charity [[Action for Children|NCH]]. He became President of the charity [[No Smoking Day]] in October 2008. The charity runs the annual health awareness campaign – helping people who want to [[Smoking cessation|stop smoking]].{{cite news |first= |last= |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/7406568/Smokers-can-use-Facebook-to-quit.html# |title=Smokers can use Facebook to quit |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=10 March 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2012 |location=London}} In August 2010, he agreed to become [[Patron]] of PC David Rathband's Blue Lamp Foundation, a charity established by the Northumbria Police Constable David Rathband, who was blinded by [[gunshot wounds]] in the [[2010 Northumbria Police manhunt]].{{cite web |first=Daniel |last=Salisbury-Jones |url=http://tyneandwear.sky.com/news/article/24130 |title=TV Dragon Duncan Bannatyne Plays Blind Football For PC Rathband's Blue Lamp Foundation |publisher=tyneandwear.sky.com |date=1 July 2012 |accessdate=10 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120703063403/http://tyneandwear.sky.com/news/article/24130 |archivedate=3 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ==Political activity== Bannatyne supported the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] under [[Margaret Thatcher]], but switched to support [[New Labour]] under [[Tony Blair]] and [[Gordon Brown]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/this_week/7637606.stm|title=Dragon Bannatyne backs Brown|publisher=BBC News|date=26 September 2008|accessdate=23 March 2010}} On appearing on the ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]'' panel on 7 February 2008, he revealed having been a donor to the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] under Blair. He also voiced his support for Brown, but criticised the [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]] for what he described as "petty squabbles based on personal ambition".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/question_time/7231128.stm|title=This Week's Panel, BBC News' Question Time website|publisher=BBC News|date=6 February 2008|accessdate=23 March 2010}} In March 2011, Bannatyne appeared to switch political affiliations again, by backing certain measures imposed in [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|Chancellor]] [[George Osborne]]'s budget even though he mocked the government a few months earlier.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12854935|work=[[BBC News]]|title=Budget 2011: Dragons' Den star backs Osborne|date=24 March 2011}} In April 2015, a week after signing a letter to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' supporting the Conservative Party in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 General Election]], he reversed his position, and pledged his vote to Labour, praising leader [[Ed Miliband]]'s "courage" in pledging to scrap [[List of people with non-domiciled status in the UK|non-domiciled tax status]].{{cite news | title = Duncan Bannatyne is voting for Ed Miliband because of his pledge to take on non-dom tax status | last = Stone | first = Jon | work = [[The Independent]] | date = 8 April 2015 | accessdate = 2015-04-08 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/duncan-bannatyne-says-hell-vote-labour-because-of-ed-milibands-courage-in-taking-on-nondom-tax-status-10161411.html | quote = Dragon’s Den star Duncan Bannatyne has said he will vote Labour because of Ed Miliband’s “courage” in pledging to scrap non-domiciled tax status. }} Duncan voted Brexit.{{Cite web|url=https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/brexit/2016/06/celebrity-brexit-wars-which-famous-people-are-and-against-leaving-eu|title=Celebrity Brexit wars: which famous people are for and against leaving the EU?|website=www.newstatesman.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}} ==Personal life== Bannatyne married Nigora Whitehorn in Portugal on 3 June 2017.{{cite news|last1=Metro.co.uk|first1=Sarah Robertson for|title=Former Dragon's Den star Duncan Bannatyne weds Nigora Whitehorn|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/06/04/duncan-bannatyne-marries-fiancee-nigora-whitehorn-in-stunning-beachside-ceremony-6682735/|work=Metro|date=4 June 2017}} Bannatyne has four children by his first wife, Gail (m. 1983[http://www.genesreunited.co.uk/search/results?sourcecategory=life%20events%20%28bmds%29&lastname=brodie&eventyear=1983&eventyear_offset=0&collection=marriages%2B%2526%2Bdivorces&page=1 Genes Reunited from UK official records], Retrieved 30 June 2013): Hollie, Abigail, Jennifer and Eve; two with his second wife, Joanne (m. 2006): Emily (b. 1999)[http://www.genesreunited.co.uk/search/results?sourcecategory=life%20events%20%28bmds%29&firstname=emily&firstname_variants=true&lastname=bannatyne&birthyear=2003&birthyear_offset=10 Genes Reunited from UK official records], Retrieved 30 June 2013 and Thomas (b. 2002).[http://www.genesreunited.co.uk/search/results?sourcecategory=life%20events%20%28bmds%29&firstname=tom%20&firstname_variants=true&lastname=bannatyne&birthyear=2003&birthyear_offset=10 Genes Reunited from UK official records], Retrieved 30 June 2013 He also has two grandchildren, Ava and Austin, from his eldest daughter.{{cite news|url=http://en.goldenmap.com/Duncan_Bannatyne|title= Duncan Bannatyne: The life of me |publisher=GoldenMap|date=20 August 2011|location=London|first=|last=}} He currently lives in [[Portugal]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.aplaceinthesun.com/articles/2016/06/duncan-bannatyne-on-the-algarve|title=Duncan Bannatyne on the Algarve|website=www.aplaceinthesun.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}} Bannatyne was awarded an honorary [[Doctorate of Science]] (D.Sc.) by [[Glasgow Caledonian University]] on 5 July 2006 for services to business and charity. He was also awarded an honorary Doctorate of Business Administration (DBA) from [[Teesside University]], on 6 February 2009. His 60th birthday was celebrated at Murano's in [[London]], with celebrities such as [[David Coulthard]], [[James Caan (entrepreneur)|James Caan]], [[Theo Paphitis]] and [[Anna Ryder Richardson]]. A second party was held in the [[North East England|North East of England]] and was headlined by UK soul singer [[Beverley Knight]] and featured [[Chesney Hawkes]], with the festivities occurring in a converted warehouse in [[Darlington]], [[County Durham]].[http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/4111333.Bannatyne_tells_birthday_guests__I_will_never_retire/ Bannatyne tells birthday guests: I will never retire Monday 9 February 2009]. The Northern Echo (9 February 2009). Retrieved on 28 March 2012.[http://www.impacttechnical.co.uk/corpcases.htm Impact Technical: Case Studies – Duncan Bannatyne's 60th Birthday Celebrations, 7 February 2009 – Darlington] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826121427/http://www.impacttechnical.co.uk/corpcases.htm |date=26 August 2014 }} He openly discussed having had [[cosmetic surgery]] under his eyes on ''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'';''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'', 7 May 2009. had an acting role in the [[Tyne Tees Television]] comedy pilot ''Girl's Club'' where amongst other actors, he performed alongside the actress [[Georgia Taylor]].[http://www.georgiataylor.co.uk/downloads4.html Georgia Taylor website: Liz (Georgia) and Julie (Lucy Blackie) pitch their night club idea to Dragon Duncan Bannatyne. (downloadable clip)] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120802015958/http://www.georgiataylor.co.uk/downloads4.html |date=2 August 2012 }}. Georgiataylor.co.uk. Retrieved on 28 March 2012. In 2011, he revealed that he suffers from [[prosopagnosia]].{{cite news |last=Tobin |first=Lucy |title=Researchers explore problems of 'face blindness' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/20/face-blindness-research |work=The Guardian |accessdate=23 July 2012 |location=London |date=20 June 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website}} * {{IMDb name|id=1832193|name=Duncan Bannatyne}} * [http://www.newstatesman.com/economy/2010/04/interview-banks-doms Interview – April 2010] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bannatyne, Duncan}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:Scottish non-fiction writers]] [[Category:People with prosopagnosia]] [[Category:People from Clydebank]] [[Category:People educated at Clydebank High School]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:British Eurosceptics]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = General | name = Emilio Madero González | honorific_suffix = | image = Huerta Madero Villa.jpg | image_size = 300px | alt = | caption = Madero in 1912. Left to right: [[Victoriano Huerta]], Emilio Madero, and [[Pancho Villa]]. | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | nickname = | birth_date = {{birth date|1880|8|8|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Parras de la Fuente]], [[Coahuila]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1962|1|16|1880|8|8|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Mexico City]], [[Federal District]] | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = | allegiance = | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = | battles = [[Mexican Revolution]] | battles_label = | awards = | memorials = | spouse = Mercedes Belden Gutiérrez{{cite web|url=http://www.familiamadero.com/genealogia/individual.php?pid=I3304&ged=Madero03Oct06.ged |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130629044820/http://www.familiamadero.com/genealogia/individual.php?pid=I3304&ged=Madero03Oct06.ged |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 June 2013 |title=Emilio Madero González |website=Familia Madero |language=Spanish |accessdate=7 January 2015 }} | relations = Brothers: [[Ernesto Madero]]
[[Francisco I. Madero]]
[[Gustavo A. Madero]]
Children: [[Pablo Emilio Madero]] | laterwork = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | website = | module = }} General '''Emilio Madero González''' (8 August 1880 – 16 January 1962) was a Mexican soldier who participated in the [[Mexican Revolution]], and the brother of [[Francisco I. Madero]]. == Biography == === Early life === Emilio Madero was born in [[Parras]], [[Coahuila]], on 8 August 1880, the sixth son of Francisco Madero Hernández and Mercedes González Treviño. He was the brother of [[Francisco I. Madero]], the leader of the [[Mexican Revolution]]. === Mexican Revolution === He participated in the Madero movement during the [[Mexican Revolution]]. In April 1911 he led the forces which conquered the Mexican state of [[Durango]], capturing [[Mapimí, Durango|Mapimí]], [[Lerdo, Durango|Lerdo]], and [[Gómez Palacio, Durango|Gómez Palacio]]. In May 1911 he led the assault on [[Torreón]], which was a key location to seizing control of the surrounding area. However, when his [[Maderistas]] finally took the city on 15 May, they were joined by a local mob and [[Torreón massacre|massacred the city's Chinese residents]]. Madero finally managed to bring them under control, but not until 10 hours had passed and over 300 Chinese lay dead.{{cite journal |last=Jacques |first=Leo M. Dambourges |date=Autumn 1974 |title=The Chinese Massacre in Torreon (Coahuila) in 1911 |jstor=40168453 |journal=[[Arizona and the West]] |publisher=[[University of Arizona Press]] |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=233–246 |via=[[JSTOR]] |subscription=yes }} He had difficulty maintaining control of the area, though, and in June was forced to form a group of loyal men, who he paid [[Mexican peso|$]]1.50 a day, to control rebellious former Maderistas.{{cite book |last=Katz |first=Friedrich |date=1988 |title=Riot, Rebellion, and Revolution: Rural Social Conflict in Mexico |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RwwABAAAQBAJ |location=Princeton, New Jersey |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |page=482 |isbn=0-691-07739-8}} He was then aligned to the [[División del Norte]]{{cite book |last=Katz |first=Friedrich |date=1998 |title=The Life and Times of Pancho Villa |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XAIcq6AJ3OwC |location=Stanford, California |publisher=[[Stanford University Press]] |isbn=9780804730464 }}{{rp|442, 462}} in 1912 fighting [[Pascual Orozco]] under General [[Victoriano Huerta]] as a Colonel.{{cite news |date=15 May 1912 |title=Federals Occupy Orozco's Camp: General Huerta Advances to Yermo, Recently Headquarters of the Rebels |newspaper=[[San Francisco Call]] |location=San Francisco }} During this time he was instrumental in saving [[Pancho Villa]] from execution, arguing for his life with Huerta, who wanted him out of the way.{{cite book |last=O'Reilly |first=Edward S. |author-link1=Tex O'Reilly |date=2012 |title=Roving And Fighting (Adventures Under Four Flags) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=684wP_LjC1gC&pg=PT199&q=Emilio%20Madero#v=snippet&q=Emilio%20Madero&f=false |publisher=JazzyBee Verlag Jürgen Beck |oclc=550664}} Madero married Mercedes Belden Gutiérrez on 27 January 1913 in [[Monterrey]], [[Nuevo León]].{{cite web |url=http://gw.geneanet.org/sanchiz?lang=en&p=emilio&n=madero+gonzalez# |title=Emilio Madero González |author=Javier E SANCHIZ RUIZ |website=GeneaNet |accessdate=13 January 2015 }} The couple had four children, including [[Pablo Emilio Madero Belden]],{{cite book |last=Camp |first=Roderic Ai |date=1995 |title=Mexican Political Biographies, 1935–1993 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HzliP-e4qnUC |edition=3 |location=Austin, Texas |publisher=[[University of Texas Press]] |page=421 |isbn=0-292-71174-3 }} who was inspired to go into politics on his father's account.{{cite book |last=Camp |first=Roderic Ai |date=1995 |title=Political Recruitment across Two Centuries: Mexico, 1884–1991 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CShMAgAAQBAJ |location=Austin, Texas |publisher=[[University of Texas Press]] |isbn=0-292-71172-7 }} === Exile === [[File:Emilio Madero cropped 2.jpg|thumb|right|Emilio Madero (center) between [[Álvaro Obregón]] (left) and [[Pancho Villa]] (right) at [[Fort Bliss]] on 27 August 1914]] Madero was in [[San Pedro, Coahuila]], with [[Venustiano Carranza]] during ''[[Ten Tragic Days|La Decena Trágica]]'' in February 1913.{{cite news |title=Intervention Will Save Madero From Injustice |date=22 February 1913 |newspaper=[[Bisbee Daily Review]] |location=Bisbee, Arizona |publisher=[[Wick Newspaper Group]] |via=[[Chronicling America]] }}{{cite news |title=Another Madero Reported Killed: Raoul Madero Reported Killed |date=27 February 1913 |newspaper=[[San Francisco Call]] |location=San Francisco, California |via=[[California Digital Newspaper Collection]] }} Following the death of his brother Francisco, it was reported that he had been shot and killed just north of Monterrey on 26 February; according to rumor he had been overtaken by General Trevino between [[Villaldama, Nuevo León|Villaldama]] and [[Bustamante, Nuevo Leon|Bustamante]] while leading a group of 35 to join a force of rebels in [[Nuevo Laredo|Laredo]]. The report was declared false the next day.{{cite book |date=1913 |title=New York Times Index for the Published News |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G-4_AQAAMAAJ |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=120–121 }}{{cite book |date=1913 |title=The Commercial & Financial Chronicle ...: A Weekly … |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HwU8AQAAMAAJ |location=New York |publisher=[[Commercial & Financial Chronicle]] |volume=96 |page=591 }}{{cite news |date=26 February 1913 |title=Emilio Madero Is Shot To Death |url=http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=TUC19130226.2.1 |newspaper=[[Urbana Courier-Herald]] |location=Urbana, Illinois |accessdate=7 January 2015 |via=[[Illinois Newspaper Project|INP]] }} On 6 March, he was forced to flee Mexico with another brother, General [[Raúl Madero (General)|Raúl Madero]], and the two swore to avenge the President's death. He had returned to Mexico by August 1914, and was in Chihuahua with Pancho Villa.{{cite news |date=1 August 1914 |title=Flat Denial From Villa: General Declares He Never Endorsed Emilio Madero For Presidency |url=http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth197111/m1/1/zoom/ |newspaper=El Paso Morning Times |location=El Paso, Texas |accessdate=12 January 2015 }} In early 1915, Madero led 2,000 troops to capture [[Saltillo]] under the command of General [[Felipe Ángeles]],{{cite book |last=Quintana |first=Alejandro |date=2012 |title=Pancho Villa: A Biography |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u_JDsWQ4Z2QC |location=Santa Barbara, California |publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]] |page=116 |isbn=978-0-313-38095-2 }} later participating in a cavalry charge on 8 January that resulted in the capture of 3,000 prisoners in [[Ramos Arizpe]].{{cite book |last=Salas |first=Elizabeth |date=2001 |title=Soldaderas in the Mexican Military: Myth and History |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_-HTGiDaXi0C |location=Austin, Texas |publisher=[[University of Texas Press]] |page=65 |isbn=0-292-77638-1 }} Following the appointment of [[Roque González Garza]] as [[President of Mexico|President]], Madero was made [[Governor of Sinaloa|governor]] of [[Sinaloa]].{{cite book |date=April 1915 |title=Information Quarterly |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cWI9AAAAYAAJ&q=%22emilio%20madero%22#v=snippet&q=%22emilio%20madero%22&f=false |location=New York City |publisher=[[R.R. Bowker]] |volume=1 }} Later that same year, however, on 12 October 1915, Emilio and Raúl refused to join Villa in waging [[guerrilla warfare]].{{rp|518}}{{cite book |date=1915 |title=New York Times Index for the Published News |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uvI_AQAAMAAJ |location=New York |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |page=315 |accessdate=7 January 2015 }} Madero was still abroad in 1918, and was living in [[San Antonio]].{{cite book |last=Rosales |first=F. Arturo |date=1999 |title=Pobre Raza!: Violence, Justice, and Mobilization among México Lindo Immigrants, 1900–1936 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QW44Dk6sxzsC |location=Austin, Texas |publisher=[[University of Texas Press]] |page=29 |isbn=0-292-77094-4 }} By 1921 he had returned to Mexico, and was living on a farm in [[San Pedro, Coahuila|San Pedro]]. Madero and his family went into exile again in 1926. They spent a year in [[California]] and two in [[Texas]] before returning to Mexico in 1929.{{cite book |editor1-last=Gil |editor1-first=Carlos B. |date=1992 |title=Hope and Frustration: Interviews with Leaders of Mexico's Political Opposition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=moAq2TPef4YC |location=Wilmington, Delaware |publisher=Scholarly Resources, Inc. |page=122 |isbn=0-8420-2395-X }} === Later life === He was the leader of the [[Revolutionary Party of National Unification]] until 1940, when he was removed for calling the party "paralyzed" due to lack of communication with leader [[Juan Andreu Almazán]].{{cite book |last=Navarro |first=Aaron W. |date=2010 |title=Political Intelligence and the Creation of Modern Mexico, 1938–1954 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hqvmyUcrXg8C |publisher=[[Pennsylvania State University Press]] |page=69 |isbn=978-0-271-03705-9 }} Madero died in [[Mexico City]] on 16 January 1962, and was buried in the [[Panteón Francés de la Piedad]].{{cite web |url=http://www.inah.gob.mx/boletin/4-publicaciones/7151-el-panteon-frances-una-joya-de-la-arquitectura-funeraria |title=El Panteón Francés, una joya de la arquitectura funeraria |date=14 April 2014 |website=[[Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia]] |language=Spanish |accessdate=12 January 2015 }} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{commonscat-inline}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Madero, Emilio}} [[Category:1880 births]] [[Category:1962 deaths]] [[Category:People of the Mexican Revolution]] [[Category:People from Parras, Coahuila]] [[Category:Politicians from Coahuila]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = George Gallup Jr. | image = | birth_name = George Horace Gallup Jr. | birth_date = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1930|4|9}} | birth_place = [[Evanston, Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|11|21|1930|4|9}} | death_place = [[Princeton, New Jersey]] | occupation = Pollster | networth = | spouse = Kingsley Hubby | children = Alison
Kingsley
George | alma_mater = [[Princeton University]] | website = | footnotes = }} '''George Horace Gallup Jr.''' (April 9, 1930 – November 21, 2011) was an American pollster, writer and executive at [[The Gallup Organization]], which had been founded by his father, [[George Gallup]].{{cite news|title=N.Y. Times reporter Tom Wicker was acclaimed for Kennedy assassination coverage |url=http://www.freep.com/article/20111126/NEWS07/111260407/N-Y-Times-reporter-Tom-Wicker-was-acclaimed-for-Kennedy-assassination-coverage |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=November 26, 2011 |accessdate=November 26, 2011}} Gallup expanded the scope of the [[Gallup Poll]] to encompass a wider variety of topics, ranging from the outlook of American [[young people]] to religious beliefs. Much of Gallup's writings and research focused on religion and [[spirituality]] in the United States. His works included ''The Saints Among Us'', published in 1992, and ''The Next American Spirituality'', published in 2002. Born in [[Evanston, Illinois]], Gallup graduated from the [[Lawrenceville School]] in 1948{{cite web|url=http://www.lawrenceville.org/about/history/notable-alumni/index.aspx |title=NOTABLE ALUMNI |publisher=The Lawrenceville School |accessdate=October 16, 2014 }} and received a [[bachelor's degree]] in religion from [[Princeton University]] in 1953. In 1954, Gallup joined his father's polling company, The Gallup Organization, where he worked until his retirement in 2004. He and his brother, Alec Gallup, became co-chairmen of the company upon their father's death.{{cite news|first=Kate|last=Zernike|title=George Gallup Jr., of Polling Family, Dies at 81 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/23/us/george-gallup-jr-of-polling-family-dies-at-81.html |work=[[New York Times]] |date=November 22, 2011 |accessdate=November 26, 2011}} George Gallup was diagnosed with liver cancer in 2010. He died in [[Princeton, New Jersey]], on November 21, 2011, at the age of 81. He was married to Kingsley Hubby, with whom he had three children. He was a devout Episcopalian, who once considered the ministry but instead served as an active [[layman]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/23/us/george-gallup-jr-of-polling-family-dies-at-81.html|title=George Gallup Jr., of Polling Family, Dies at 81|date=November 23, 2011|work=The New York Times}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gallup, George Jr.}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:American statisticians]] [[Category:American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Pollsters]] [[Category:Lawrenceville School alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Evanston, Illinois]] [[Category:Deaths from liver cancer]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New Jersey]]

{{distinguish|Gregory Breit}} '''Gregory Bright''' (born 1954) is a [[New Orleans]] native who was [[Conviction|convicted]] of [[Second degree murder|second-degree]] [[murder]] in 1974 at the [[Ageing|age]] of 20. He was sentenced to [[Life imprisonment|life]] without [[parole]], served at the [[Louisiana State Penitentiary]].<ref>Jennings, Doug. [https://www.webcitation.org/5wQYGwOgM?url=http://www.dailyutahchronicle.com/news/never-fight-a-shark-in-water-highlights-man-exonerated-of-murder-1.2462547 "Never Fight a Shark in Water’ highlights man exonerated of murder".] Daily Utah Chronicle, February 9, 2011. Retrieved 2011-02-11</ref> After several years of [[appeal]]s, Mr. Bright was granted a new [[trial]] in 2001 on the grounds that the prosecution had withheld [[Evidence (law)|evidence]] from the [[Defense (legal)|defense]] in his previous trial. On June 24, 2003, after 27 ½ [[year]]s in [[prison]] for a [[crime]] they did not commit, Mr. Bright and [[Earl Truvia]] were both released after the [[Orleans Parish, Louisiana|Orleans]] [[List of parishes in Louisiana|Parish]] [[district attorney]] dismissed all charges. When Bright was released from prison, the State of [[Louisiana]] only provided a [[United States dollar|US]]$10 [[Cheque|check]] and [[Bin bag|garbage bags]] full of legal paperwork.
Bright speaks around the [[United States of America|country]] about his wrongful [[incarceration]] and life since prison. He can also be seen on [[HBO|HBO's]] [[Treme (TV series)|Tremé]], the [[American Horror Story: Coven|third season]] of [[FX (TV channel)|FX's]] [[American Horror Story]] and [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT's]] [[Memphis Beat]].
== Innocence Project New Orleans == In 2010, Mr. Bright joined [[Innocence Project]] New Orleans as ''Assistant Education and Outreach Director''.<ref>Innocence Project New Orleans [http://ip-no.org/staff Staff Directory] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113091529/http://www.ip-no.org/staff |date=2011-11-13 }}. Retrieved 2011-02-15</ref>
== Never Fight a Shark in Water == [[Lara Naughton]] and Gregory Bright collaborated on a documentary play based on Bright's words and recollections that exposes the failure of the criminal justice system, life in prison, and Bright's journey to freedom and forgiveness. With its first showing in 2010, the play is now performed by Bright himself under Naughton's direction.
